conclusion: The problem involves analyzing how shadows A, B, C, and D change in position and size when the light source moves forward above the objects.
When the light source moves forward, the shadows will shift backward, away from the direction of the light source.
Shadows are cast opposite to the direction of the light source.
The size of the shadows will generally increase as the light source moves closer to the objects (i.e., decreases in height above the objects).
The increase in shadow size occurs because the light rays spread out more, causing the shadow to enlarge.
If the light source moves forward but also higher, the shadows might not enlarge as much.
Based on typical scenarios where the primary movement is forward without a significant increase in height, the shadows are likely to become larger.
The shapes of the shadows may become more elongated, especially if the light source is lower.
Elongation of shadows happens in the direction opposite to the light source.
Summary: Shadows A, B, C, D will shift backward, likely increase in size, and become more elongated.
